BC-CIR-RETINAL-IMPLANTS-NYT 
ELECTRONIC RETINAL IMPLANTS MERGING COMPUTERS AND NEURONS 

  
(ATTN: Md., Mass., Ill.)  (Circuits)  
(jt) 
 By ANNE EISENBERG    
 c.1999 N.Y. Times News Service    

   Electronic retinal implants are not the bionic eyes of science
fiction, the sort that Geordi on ``Star Trek'' had, but they are
getting closer. Work on these implants, which would be among the
first marriages of computers and neurons, is progressing fast,
researchers say, partly because of the increasing power of computer
chips. Such implants may start giving blind patients limited vision
within a decade.

   ``We have third- and fourth-generation computer chips that can
electrically stimulate the retina,'' said Dr. Mark Humayun, a
retinal surgeon, biomedical engineer and professor at the Wilmer
Eye Institute at Johns Hopkins University. ``The way the
engineering and biological testing have been going, we feel very
confident we'll have a prototype for human use not in 10 or 20
years, but in 2 to 5 years.''

   Humayun and Dr. Eugene de Juan Jr. lead a group of scientists,
surgeons, electrophysiologists and electrical engineers, one of a
handful of multidisciplinary teams in the United States and Germany
that are working on prototypes for retinal prostheses. At least
three start-up companies have also formed to develop the new
implants.

   The surviving neural tissue in the eyes of blind patients can
respond to electrical stimulation. When blind patients' retinas
were stimulated by handheld electrodes, precursors of the tiny
silicon chips the team hopes to implant in the future, the patients
reported that they could see points of light, dim outlines and the
shapes of letters, Humayun said. ``We can get patients to see a
simple geometric shape like a box or a letter like `H.' It's very
encouraging.''

   Humayun does not expect to replicate the complexities of natural
vision. ``Simply providing mobility-type vision, or the ability to
distinguish between light and dark to patients who are completely
blind, will have far-reaching consequences,'' he said. ``Being able
to see the outline of a person or doorway makes a different world
than the world of total blackness.''

   The new prostheses will work by electrically stimulating the
millions of neurons in the retina, a thin layer of light receptors
and other neurons in the back of the eye. The silicon chip that
stimulates the nerves will be placed either near the retinal layer
where nerve impulses are sent to the brain, a method being
developed by the Johns Hopkins group and a group at the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard, or close to the
front-line light-detecting cells, the rods and cones, a method
developed by Dr. Alan Chow and his brother Vincent, co-founders of
Optobionics in Wheaton, Ill.

   ``Some patients are blind because of light-sensing cells that
have degenerated or died,'' Humayun explained. ``But the rest of
the retina is made of neurons that are relatively intact. Our idea
_ and the idea of other teams in the field _ is to jump-start these
other retinal neurons that are waiting in the dark.''

   The microelectronic prostheses are designed to help the
estimated 30 million people worldwide who suffer from two diseases
of the retina: macular degeneration and retinitis pigmentosa. Even
when the the rods and cones in these patients have died,
researchers say, the remaining retinal circuitry, when stimulated
by electrical signals, is powerful enough to send signals through
the optic nerve.

   ``In both of these diseases, the rods and cones degenerate,''
said Dr. John Wyatt, a professor of electrical engineering at MIT.
Wyatt and Dr. Joseph Rizzo, a neuro-ophthalmologist at Harvard
Medical School, lead a research group that has worked for nearly 10
years on a retinal implant that would stimulate the cells that
carry signals from the retina to the brain, the ganglion cells,
which are close to the lining in the back of the eye. ``The rods
and cones have died, but the ganglion cells that communicate
straight to the brain still live in substantial numbers and
apparently still work,'' Wyatt said.

   Wyatt emphasized that the new devices were designed for
degenerative diseases of the retina and not for damage to the optic
nerve or brain. In particular, he said the devices would not be
helpful for vision loss from glaucoma, in which there is damage to
the optic nerve.

   The Harvard-MIT group plans to use at least two silicon
microchips. One chip, the signal processor, will be mounted on a
pair of glasses, along with a camera. Once an image is captured, it
will be transmitted wirelessly to a second chip embedded in the
eye. After that chip receives the signal, it will stimulate the
retina.

   The MIT-Harvard group has not yet implanted a microchip in a
person but has started experiments in which the retinas of blind
patients are stimulated with microelectrodes. Earlier this year,
the group implanted a microelectrode array, three millimeters wide
and one-eighth the thickness of a human hair, in the group's third
patient and left it in place for about three hours. The technical
challenges were daunting because the device had to be inserted in
such a way that both it and the retina survived unharmed, Wyatt
said.

   The retina is delicate, ``about as strong as one layer of wet
Kleenex,'' he said. If torn, the retina will become detached from
the lining of the eye; if compressed, it can squeeze the blood
vessels.

   ``Right now we are only doing short-term experiments of a few
hours in humans,'' Wyatt said. ``Presumably our patients would
continue to learn if the prosthesis were left in the eye for
months.'' The ability of the brain to learn and adapt over time is
expected to be an asset once the devices remain in place longer.

   The researchers hope that electronic implants that bypass
damaged rods and cones in the eye may one day be as successful as
the cochlear implants used in the inner ear. Since the 1970s,
cochlear implants have restored some hearing to thousands of deaf
patients, and their ability to hear often improves over time as the
brain adapts.

   ``In cochlear implants, patients continued to show improved word
recognition scores as the years passed,'' Wyatt said.

   While the strategy of both the John Hopkins and Harvard-MIT
groups is to place the stimulation near the ganglion cells, which
is called an epiretinal approach, Optobionics has developed a
silicon chip that is designed to stimulate the area near the rods
and cones; it will need no wiring because it will be powered by
incident light.

   ``Ours is a simple silicon chip embedded with thousands of
microscopic solar cells,'' said Chow, of Optobionics. ``The
placement of the chip underneath the retina is actually closer to
the remnants of the rods and cones than the epiretinal approach,
allowing better processing of the signal by the remainder of the
retina.''

   ``We have looked at the device mostly in rabbits and rats,''
Chow said. ``The implants are biocompatible and will continue to
function over long periods of time.'' Chow said he hoped to begin
clinical trials with patients with retinitis pigmentosa within a
year and a half.

   ``When we are satisfied with the level of safety and
biocompatibility, we will pull together data to submit to the Food
and Drug Administration,'' he said.

   Wyatt cautioned that many problems remained to be solved.

   ``The data are encouraging, but they are not yet good enough to
justify chronic implantation in humans. We have a ways to go.''
